text: Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: The super hormones for the three months also make you more tired, but not really that much more because once we lower your testosterone down to what we call castrate levels, to go from castrate to super castrate, people don’t complain about more tiredness. Patient: Right. Doctor: So um there are some things we watch and your blood tests to make sure you’re tolerating the drugs all right, but that’s not the big issue. Tiredness is the issue. So then we add chemo in and really we give the chemo to you four times on a Monday – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - three weeks apart. Um, the the actual um chemo itself, you don’t get sick, you don’t throw up. We have all the medicines that stop that from happening. Anything that throw up We’re just really good at it. Uhm, Patient: Sure. Doctor: And during that time you’re more tired is when your blood counts are low when you’re fighting infection. So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. And the chemo is what we’re here to talk about today- Patient: Okay. text: Patient: No. Doctor: No. Patient: Did you, did you see that Harvard study? Patient: All of whom. All of whom. All eight, including the, the black guy who did this study from Harvard, were convinced that they had Native American, uh, genes. None. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
